questions.prompt: How does an ideal diode behave when forward-biased?
questions.explanation: In the ideal model, a forward-biased diode is treated as a perfect conductor, effectively acting as a short circuit with zero voltage drop across it.

questions.prompt: How does an ideal diode behave when reverse-biased?
questions.explanation: When reverse-biased, an ideal diode blocks all current flow, effectively acting as an open circuit with infinite resistance to current.

questions.prompt: What is the voltage drop across an ideal diode when it is conducting (ON)?
questions.explanation: Since an ideal diode has zero resistance when conducting, Ohm's law implies that the voltage drop across it must be exactly zero volts regardless of current.

questions.prompt: Which statement best describes the IV characteristic of an ideal diode?
options: Zero current for V < 0, vertical line at V = 0
questions.correctAnswer: Zero current for V < 0, vertical line at V = 0
questions.explanation: The I-V curve of an ideal diode consists of two linear segments: zero current for negative voltages (reverse bias) and infinite slope (vertical) at V=0 for positive current.

questions.prompt: What happens if you try to force negative current through an ideal diode?
questions.explanation: By definition, an ideal diode allows current to flow in only one direction (the direction of the arrow). It physically prevents any negative (reverse) current flow.

questions.prompt: The ideal diode model is most useful for:
options: Quick initial analysis and understanding logic
questions.correctAnswer: Quick initial analysis and understanding logic
questions.explanation: The ideal diode model simplifies analysis by ignoring small voltage drops and leakages, making it perfect for determining the ON/OFF state logic of diodes in a circuit.

questions.prompt: In a series circuit with a voltage source V > 0 and a resistor, an ideal diode is ON if:
options: Anode is connected to positive terminal
Cathode is connected to positive terminal
questions.correctAnswer: Anode is connected to positive terminal
questions.explanation: For the diode to turn ON (forward bias), the anode must be at a higher potential than the cathode. Connecting the anode to the positive source terminal satisfies this.

questions.prompt: Does an ideal diode dissipate power?
questions.explanation: When ON, voltage is zero (P=0*I=0). When OFF, current is zero (P=V*0=0). Thus, an ideal diode never dissipates power.

questions.prompt: What is the 'Threshold Voltage' of an ideal diode?
questions.explanation: Unlike real silicon diodes which have a threshold of ~0.7V, the ideal diode model assumes conduction begins immediately as the voltage becomes positive, i.e., at 0V.

questions.prompt: Can an ideal diode rectify an AC signal?
questions.explanation: Yes, an ideal diode is a perfect rectifier. It will pass one half-cycle of an AC waveform completely and block the other half-cycle completely with no losses.
